definition: more than one can attend to (idiom)/deluged (with inquiries etc)/overwhelmed (by the beauty of the scenery)
surname Ying
to agree (to do sth)/should/ought to/must/(legal) shall
to answer/to respond/to comply with/to deal or cope with
to receive/to answer (the phone)/to meet or welcome sb/to connect/to catch/to join/to extend/to take one's turn on duty/to take over for sb
(negative prefix)/not/no
leisure

sentences.chinese: 來訪者多得讓他應接不暇。

sentences.english: The firm has more clients than it can take care of.
sentences.chinese: 這家商行的主顧多得應接不暇。

sentences.english: You do not have to take in new orders.
sentences.chinese: 新的定貨單實在使他們應接不暇了。

sentences.english: We were inundated with requests for further information.
sentences.chinese: 要求提供進一步信息的人極多，我們應接不暇。

sentences.english: Three emergency cases came into the hospital at the same time and the doctors really had their hands full.
sentences.chinese: 三個急診病人被同時送到醫院，醫生們真是應接不暇。

sentences.english: He is besieged with visitors from abroad.
sentences.chinese: 海外客人紛至遝來，弄得他應接不暇。

sentences.english: We have been deluged with applications for the job.
sentences.chinese: 申請這個工作的求職信使我們應接不暇。

sentences.english: The season swamps us under wave after wave of produce.
sentences.chinese: 這個季節一波一波的農產品讓我們應接不暇。

sentences.english: They have more business than they can do now.
sentences.chinese: 現在他們的生意是應接不暇。

definition: the eye cannot take it all in (idiom); too many good things to see/a feast for the eyes
to click one's tongue in wonder (idiom)/to be astonished
lit. slap the table and shout with praise (idiom); fig. wonderful!/amazing!/great!
(idiom) to gasp in amazement/to acclaim as the peak of perfection
good and bad people intermingled
out of the ordinary
to envy/to admire
crowded with visitors/packed with tourists
to rush like ducks (idiom); the mob scrabbles madly for sth unobtainable/an unruly crowd on a wild goose chase
disordered and in a mess (idiom); all mixed up and chaotic
more and more emerge/innumerable succession/breeding like flies (idiom)
stupefied/flabbergasted
lit. to see a gap and stick in a needle (idiom); fig. to make use of every second and every inch
countless changes/constant permutation
to be clogged up/to be congested (traffic, computer network etc)
lit. dragons and snakes mingle (idiom)/fig. a mix of good people and scumbags
